intro: Bakerella grisea, commonly known as the gray baker's weed, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. The plant is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, greenish-white flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often covered with a fine layer of grayish-white hairs, giving the plant its distinctive appearance. Bakerella grisea is typically found in moist, disturbed soils along streambanks and in open woods.
